present_simple_vs_continuous.title: Present Simple vs. Continuous
present_simple_vs_continuous.subtitle: Habits (Simple) vs. Actions Now (Continuous)
present_simple_vs_continuous.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Present Simple vs. Continuous

1. Comparison:

  • Simple: General facts, routines ("I live in London").
  • Continuous: Temporary, happening now ("I am living in London for a month").

2. Key Difference:
Always/Every day = Simple
Now/At the moment = Continuous

3. Stative Verbs: Relate to feelings/thoughts (Love, hate, know, believe). Use Simple only.
✅ "I understand."
❌ "I am understanding."

explorer.correctSentence: We are watching TV right now
He reads a book every night

explorer.original: I usually (go) to work by bus.
explorer.correctSentence: I usually go to work by bus

scholar.correctSentence: He is always losing his keys
I think you are right
Do you understand this question

scholar.original: She (have) a shower at the moment.
scholar.correctSentence: She is having a shower at the moment

scholar.original: We (taste) the soup. It needs salt.
scholar.correctSentence: We are tasting the soup
The soup tastes delicious
Why are you smelling the milk
He does not seem happy today
I am seeing my doctor tomorrow
I see what you mean

specialist.original: Usually I (work) in an office, but this month I (work) from home.
specialist.correctSentence: Usually I work in an office but this month I am working from home

specialist.original: My parents (live) in London, but they (stay) with us now.
specialist.correctSentence: My parents live in London but they are staying with us now
What time does the train leave
She is being very selfish these days
I am weighing myself on the scales
This box weighs 10 kilos
What are you looking at
You look great today
We are having a party next Saturday
Who does this book belong to

past_simple_review.title: Past Simple
past_simple_review.subtitle: Finished actions in the past.
past_simple_review.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Past Simple (Review)

1. Review: Actions finished at a specific time in the past.

2. Common Markers: Yesterday, Last week, In 2010, 2 days ago.

3. Irregular Verbs: Memorize them!
Go -> Went
Buy -> Bought
Come -> Came

scholar.correctSentence: I went to the beach
She bought a new car
They ate pizza
We saw a ghost
He drank all the milk
I did not know the answer
She did not come to the party
Did you like the movie
Where did you go
I was very tired

specialist.original: When I (be) a child, I (love) candy.
specialist.correctSentence: When I was a child I loved candy
He taught me how to drive

specialist.original: We (fly) to Spain and (swim) in the sea.
specialist.correctSentence: We flew to Spain and swam in the sea
I tried to help but I could not
Who wrote this book
The sun rose at 6am
She fell and hurt her leg
They built a house in 1990
I caught the ball
What happened yesterday
specialist.hint: Subject question (no 'did' needed if asking about subject).

past_continuous.title: Past Continuous
past_continuous.subtitle: Actions in progress in the past.
past_continuous.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Past Continuous

1. Concept: Action in progress at a specific moment in the past.

2. Structure:

Was/Were + Verb-ing

3. Usage:

  • Parallel Actions: "I was reading while he was cooking."
  • Interrupted Action: "I was sleeping when the phone rang."

explorer.correctSentence: He was reading when I entered

scholar.correctSentence: I was not watching TV
They were not listening
Were you sleeping
What was he doing
Who were you talking to
It was not raining when we left
We were studying all night
The sun was shining
Birds were singing
Everybody was looking at me

specialist.original: I (walk) down the street when I (see) him.
specialist.correctSentence: I was walking down the street when I saw him
specialist.hint: Long action (Past Cont) interrupted by Short action (Past Simple).

specialist.correctSentence: While she was cooking the phone rang

specialist.original: We (drive) fast when the cop (stop) us.
specialist.correctSentence: We were driving fast when the cop stopped us
He broke his leg while he was skiing
I was not paying attention so I crashed
What were you doing at 8pm last night
She was always complaining about her job
The music was playing too loud
While I was reading my sister was watching TV
It was getting dark

present_perfect.title: Present Perfect Simple
present_perfect.subtitle: Experiences and recent events.
present_perfect.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Present Perfect

1. Concept: Past action with result in present OR life experience (time not specified).

2. Structure:

Have/Has + Past Participle (V3)

3. Usage:

  • Experience: "I have been to Paris." (In my life).
  • Recent Result: "I have lost my keys." (I don't have them now).

Markers: Ever, Never, Just, Already, Yet.

scholar.correctSentence: I have never been to Paris
scholar.hint: Never goes between have and verb.

scholar.correctSentence: She has just called me
scholar.hint: Just goes between has and verb.

scholar.correctSentence: Have you ever eaten sushi
I have not finished yet
He has already left
We have lived here for ten years
scholar.hint: For + duration (started in past, still now).

scholar.correctSentence: She has known him since 2010
Have they arrived yet
I have lost my passport
He has been ill all week

specialist.original: It is the best book I (ever/read).
specialist.correctSentence: It is the best book I have ever read

specialist.original: This is the first time I (drive) a car.
specialist.correctSentence: This is the first time I have driven a car

specialist.original: She (go) to the bank. She is not here.
specialist.correctSentence: She has gone to the bank
specialist.hint: Has gone = Went and hasn't returned.

specialist.original: I (be) to the bank. Using the ATM now.
specialist.correctSentence: I have been to the bank
I have not spoken to her for ages
How long have you known your best friend
My key I have found it

specialist.original: Look at that! Someone (break) that window.
specialist.correctSentence: Look at that Someone has broken that window
I have worked hard this week

specialist.original: She (drink) three cups of coffee today.
specialist.correctSentence: She has drunk three cups of coffee today

present_perfect_vs_past_simple.title: Present Perfect vs. Past Simple
present_perfect_vs_past_simple.subtitle: Unfinished time vs. Finished time.
present_perfect_vs_past_simple.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Pres. Perfect vs. Past Simple

1. The Golden Rule:

  • Know the time? Use Past Simple. ("I went yesterday").
  • Time not important/unfinished? Use Present Perfect. ("I have seen that movie").

✅ "I have lived here for 10 years." (Still live here -> Perfect)
✅ "I lived there for 10 years." (Moved away -> Past Simple)

explorer.original: I (live) in London for 5 years (and I still do).
explorer.correctSentence: I have lived in London for 5 years
She has visited Tokyo three times

explorer.original: He (break) his leg, so he can't walk.

explorer.correctSentence: I did not see her last night
I have not seen her today

scholar.correctSentence: Shakespeare wrote many plays
scholar.hint: Person is dead (finished time) = Past Simple.

scholar.original: My brother (write) many plays (he is alive).
scholar.correctSentence: My brother has written many plays
When did you arrive
scholar.hint: 'When' asks for specific time = Past Simple.

scholar.original: I (lose) my key. Can you help me?
scholar.correctSentence: I have lost my key

scholar.original: I (lose) my key but I found it later.
scholar.correctSentence: I lost my key but I found it later
Have you seen Ann this morning
Did you see Ann this morning

scholar.original: We (buy) a new car last week.
scholar.correctSentence: We bought a new car last week
We have bought a new car
Where were you last night

specialist.correctSentence: The Chinese invented paper
Scientists have discovered a new planet recently
I stopped smoking two years ago
I have not smoked for two years

specialist.original: My grandfather (die) before I was born.
specialist.correctSentence: My grandfather died before I was born

specialist.original: Mary (go) shopping. She'll be back soon.
specialist.correctSentence: Mary has gone shopping
Mary went shopping yesterday
How many times have you been to NYC
I grew up in Berlin
It did not rain last week

future_will.title: Future: Will
future_will.subtitle: Decisions, Offers, Promises, and Predictions.
future_will.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Future (Will)

1. Concept: Instant decisions, promises, and predictions (beliefs).

2. Structure:

Will + Base Verb

3. Usage:

  • Decision: "The phone is ringing. I'll answer it."
  • Promise: "I will help you."
  • Prediction (No evidence): "I think cars will fly in 2050."

scholar.correctSentence: I think it will rain
I promise I will not tell
Will you marry me
Don't worry I will pay
I will buy some
Maybe he will come
I hope you will pass
I will help you carry that
Do you think she will like it
I am sure they will understand

specialist.correctSentence: I will not do it again I promise

specialist.original: That bag looks heavy. I (carry) it.
specialist.correctSentence: I will carry it

specialist.original: We run out of bread. I (get) some.
specialist.correctSentence: I will get some

specialist.original: I (get) some bread. (Said before leaving house).
specialist.correctSentence: I am going to get some bread

specialist.original: If you say that again, I (scream)!
specialist.correctSentence: I will scream
I don't think he will be happy

specialist.original: Shall I open the window? Yes, yes (you/do) that.
specialist.correctSentence: Yes please do that
specialist.hint: Command/Suggestion response. Actually strict 'will' answer: Yes, please.

specialist.correctSentence: In 2050 people will live on Mars
I will get it
I will probably be a bit late

comparatives_superlatives.title: Comparatives & Superlatives
comparatives_superlatives.subtitle: Better, Best, More interesting, Most interesting.
comparatives_superlatives.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Comparatives & Superlatives

1. Comparative (2 things): -er than OR more ... than.

2. Superlative (3+ things): the -est OR the most ....

3. Examples:

  • Fast -> Faster -> The Fastest
  • Expensive -> More expensive -> The most expensive
  • Good -> Better -> The Best

explorer.original: This car is (fast) than that one.
explorer.correctSentence: This car is faster than that one

explorer.original: This book is (good) than the movie.
explorer.correctSentence: This book is better than the movie

explorer.original: A plane is (big) than a car.
explorer.correctSentence: A plane is bigger than a car

scholar.original: This exam was (difficult) than the last one.
scholar.correctSentence: This exam was more difficult than the last one
She is the most beautiful girl here
This is worse than I thought
He is the worst singer
My house is further than yours
English is easier than Chinese

scholar.original: It is the (happy) day of my life.
scholar.correctSentence: It is the happiest day of my life
Ferrari is more expensive than Fiat
Which is the most dangerous animal
Today is sunnier than yesterday

specialist.correctSentence: It is quieter inside than outside

specialist.original: The (fast) you drive, the (dangerous) it is.
specialist.correctSentence: The faster you drive the more dangerous it is

specialist.original: He is not as (old) as me.
specialist.correctSentence: He is not as old as me
This is the least expensive one
I have less money than you

specialist.original: This is the (good) pizza I've ever eaten.
specialist.correctSentence: This is the best pizza I have ever eaten
She is getting thinner and thinner

specialist.original: It is slightly (cheap) than the other.
specialist.correctSentence: It is slightly cheaper than the other

specialist.original: He is much (tall) - No, he isn't!
specialist.correctSentence: He is much taller

specialist.original: Australia is big, but Russia is (big).
specialist.correctSentence: Russia is bigger

modal_can_could.title: Modals: Can & Could
modal_can_could.subtitle: Ability, Permission, and Requests.
modal_can_could.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Modals (Can, Could, Be able to)

1. Can: General ability / Permission.

2. Could: Past ability / Possibility.

3. Be able to: Specific ability (can be used in all tenses).

✅ "I was able to finish the work yesterday." (Specific achievement)
✅ "I could swim when I was 5." (General past ability)

scholar.original: When I was young, I (could/run) fast.
scholar.correctSentence: When I was young I could run fast
She could read when she was 4
I could not sleep last night
Could you pass the salt
Could I open the window
Last year he could not speak French
Could you tell me the time
My grandmother could play piano

scholar.original: We (could/hear) the ocean from our room.
scholar.correctSentence: We could hear the ocean from our room
They could not find the house

specialist.original: I searched everywhere but I (could/not/find) it.
specialist.correctSentence: I watched everywhere but I could not find it
specialist.hint: Specific attempt (Negative). Note: For positive specific achievement in past, we usually use 'was able to', but 'could not' is fine for negative.

specialist.correctSentence: Can you see that bird
specialist.hint: Perception (Can/Could used with see, hear, smell).

specialist.correctSentence: If you practice you can win
I could lend you money
I cannot lift this
He can speak 10 languages

specialist.original: I was so tired I (could/sleep) for a week.
specialist.correctSentence: I could sleep for a week
She asked if she could go
It could rain later
You cannot be serious

modal_should.title: Modals: Should
modal_should.subtitle: Advice and Recommendations.
modal_should.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Modals (Should)

1. Concept: Advice and Recommendation.

2. Structure: Should + Base Verb.

3. Usage:

  • "You should see a doctor." (Advice)
  • "You shouldn't smoke." (Negative advice)
  • "Ought to" is a formal synonym for 'Should'.

scholar.correctSentence: You should visit the dentist
You should wear a coat
Drivers should stop at red lights
scholar.hint: Obligation/Advice (Should implies duty here, Must implies law).

scholar.correctSentence: You should not eat candy
Where should I park
What should we do
The government should help the poor
Children should listen to parents
You should be careful

scholar.original: I don't think you (should/work) so hard.
scholar.correctSentence: I don't think you should work so hard

specialist.original: If you feel sick, you (should/see) a doctor.
specialist.correctSentence: If you feel sick you should see a doctor

specialist.original: I think we (should/leave) early to avoid traffic.
specialist.correctSentence: I think we should leave early to avoid traffic
Should I invite him to the party

specialist.original: You look tired. You (should/take) a break.
specialist.correctSentence: You should take a break
You should not have said that
specialist.hint: Past regret (Should have V3) - wait this is A2, keep strict 'should + base'? Or maybe A2 allows slight complexity? Let's stick to 'You should not say that' for A2 simplicity, or just introduce the phrase. Let's stick to present advice: 'You (should/not/say) rude things.' -> 'You should not say rude things'.

specialist.correctSentence: He should arrive soon

specialist.original: There (should/be) a key under the mat.
specialist.correctSentence: There should be a key under the mat
Why should I believe you
Everyone should recycle

specialist.original: It is a great movie. You (really/should/see) it.
specialist.correctSentence: You really should see it

modal_have_to_must.title: Modals: Have to / Must
modal_have_to_must.subtitle: Obligation and Necessity.
modal_have_to_must.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Must vs. Have to

1. Must: Internal obligation (Speaker feels it's necessary).

2. Have to: External obligation (Rules, laws, someone else said so).

✅ "I must call Mom." (I want to).
✅ "I have to wear a uniform." (Rule).

3. Important Negative:
Mustn't: Prohibition (Don't do it!).
Don't have to: No obligation (You can do it if you want, but not forced).

scholar.original: In England, you (have to/drive) on the left.
scholar.correctSentence: In England you have to drive on the left
I must buy flowers
You must not touch that
You don't have to finish it today
What time do you have to leave
Does she have to work on Sundays
We must be quiet
A doctor has to be careful
I must remember to call Mom
Passengers must wear seatbelts

specialist.correctSentence: You must not tell anyone

specialist.original: You (don't/have to/tell) him if you don't want to.
specialist.correctSentence: You don't have to tell him if you don't want to
To enter you must have a ticket
Yesterday I had to work late
I didn't have to go to school yesterday
Why did you have to leave so early
All candidates must fill in this form

specialist.original: My vision is bad. I (have to/wear) glasses.
specialist.correctSentence: I have to wear glasses

specialist.original: This cake is yummy. You (must/try) it!
specialist.correctSentence: You must try it
We have to get up early tomorrow

zero_conditional.title: Zero Conditional
zero_conditional.subtitle: General Truths and Facts.
zero_conditional.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Zero Conditional

1. Concept: General truths and scientific facts.

2. Structure:

If + Present Simple, ... Present Simple

3. Examples:
✅ "If you heat ice, it melts."
✅ "If I eat too much, I feel sick."

explorer.correctSentence: If you heat ice it melts
If it rains the grass gets wet
I eat if I am hungry
If babies are hungry they cry

explorer.original: If you (mix) red and blue, you (get) purple.
explorer.correctSentence: If you mix red and blue you get purple

explorer.original: Ice (float) if you (put) it in water.
explorer.correctSentence: Ice floats if you put it in water

explorer.original: If I (be) late, my boss (be) angry.
explorer.correctSentence: If I am late my boss is angry
If you touch fire you get burned

explorer.original: If you (press) this button, the TV (turn) on.
explorer.correctSentence: If you press this button the TV turns on
I sleep well if I drink milk

scholar.correctSentence: Plants die if they do not get water
If you do not eat you get hungry
Water boils if it reaches 100 degrees

scholar.original: If my husband (cook), he (burn) the food.
scholar.correctSentence: If my husband cooks he burns the food
Snakes bite if they are scared

scholar.original: If I (drink) coffee at night, I (not/sleep).
scholar.correctSentence: If I drink coffee at night I do not sleep

scholar.original: If the sun (go) down, it (get) dark.
scholar.correctSentence: If the sun goes down it gets dark

scholar.original: You (get) green if you (mix) yellow and blue.
scholar.correctSentence: You get green if you mix yellow and blue
If you freeze water it becomes ice
Does ice melt if you heat it

specialist.original: When I (have) a headache, I (take) aspirin.
specialist.correctSentence: When I have a headache I take aspirin
Usually if I run I get tired
If you do not water plants they do not grow
Computer works better if you restart it

specialist.original: If I (wake) up early, I (go) for a run.
specialist.correctSentence: If I wake up early I go for a run
What happens if you press this
If you add 2 and 2 you get 4

specialist.original: Milk (go) bad if you (leave) it out.
specialist.correctSentence: Milk goes bad if you leave it out
Unless you study you fail
specialist.hint: Unless = If not (Zero for general rule).

specialist.original: If you (be) polite, people (be) polite back.
specialist.correctSentence: If you are polite people are polite back

first_conditional.title: First Conditional
first_conditional.subtitle: Real Possibilities in the Future.
first_conditional.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: First Conditional

1. Concept: Real possibilities in the future.

2. Structure:

If + Present Simple, ... Will + Verb

3. Examples:
✅ "If it rains, I will stay home."
❌ "If it will rain..." (No 'will' in the IF part!)

explorer.correctSentence: If it rains I will stay home
If you study you will pass

explorer.original: He (miss) the bus if he (be) late.
explorer.correctSentence: He will miss the bus if he is late
If she calls I will answer
I will cook if you wash up

explorer.original: If we (go) now, we (be) on time.
explorer.correctSentence: If we go now we will be on time
If they lose they will be sad

explorer.original: You (get) cold if you (not/wear) a coat.
explorer.correctSentence: You will get cold if you do not wear a coat

explorer.original: If I (find) your key, I (tell) you.
explorer.correctSentence: If I find your key I will tell you
The dog will bite if you touch it

scholar.original: If I (see) him, I (give) him the message.
scholar.correctSentence: If I see him I will give him the message
If you do not hurry you will be late
She will not come if she is tired
What will you do if it rains
If he does not study he will not pass

scholar.original: I (buy) a new car if I (get) the job.
scholar.correctSentence: I will buy a new car if I get the job

scholar.original: If we (not/leave) now, we (miss) the start.
scholar.correctSentence: If we do not leave now we will miss the start
If you eat that you will feel sick
Where will you go if the shop is closed

scholar.original: If the weather (be) good, we (have) a picnic.
scholar.correctSentence: If the weather is good we will have a picnic

specialist.correctSentence: Unless you hurry you will be late
I will not go unless you come too

specialist.original: If I (become) rich, I (travel) the world.
specialist.correctSentence: If I become rich I will travel the world
Who will you call if there is an accident

specialist.original: If you (keep) eating this, you (get) fat.
specialist.correctSentence: If you keep eating this you will get fat
I will call the police if you do not stop

specialist.original: If she (pass) her exam, she (have) a party.
specialist.correctSentence: If she passes her exam she will have a party
You will fail unless you work harder

specialist.original: If anyone (ask), I (be) in my office.
specialist.correctSentence: If anyone asks I will be in my office
Everything will be fine if you calm down

quantifiers.title: Quantifiers
quantifiers.subtitle: Much, Many, A lot of, A few, A little.
quantifiers.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Quantifiers

1. Countable (Apples, Cars): Many, A few, Few.

2. Uncountable (Water, Time): Much, A little, Little.

3. Both: A lot of, Some, Any.

✅ "How many apples?"
✅ "How much time?"

Tip: 'A few/A little' is positive (I have some). 'Few/Little' is negative (Not enough).

explorer.correctSentence: She has a lot of friends
He drinks a lot of coffee

scholar.correctSentence: How much milk do we need
How many cars are there
I have few friends
I have little hope
There isn't much traffic today
There aren't many options
Would you like some tea
There isn't any bread left

scholar.original: She spends (too much) time on phone.
scholar.correctSentence: She spends too much time on phone
We visited a lot of places

specialist.original: I have (a few) books, but not many.
specialist.correctSentence: I have a few books but not many
Very few people know this secret

specialist.original: She put (a little) sugar in her tea.
specialist.correctSentence: She put a little sugar in her tea
There is very little water left
How much does it cost
I have plenty of time
There are lots of mistakes
Is there any milk
Can I have some water
Too many cooks spoil the broth

gerunds_infinitives.title: Gerunds & Infinitives
gerunds_infinitives.subtitle: Verb + -ing vs. Verb + to...
gerunds_infinitives.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Gerunds & Infinitives

1. Gerund (Verb-ing): Used after prepositions and certain verbs (Enjoy, Mind, Suggest).

  • "I enjoy swimming."

2. Infinitive (To + Verb): Used after adjectives and certain verbs (Want, Need, Hope, Decide).

  • "I want to go."

3. Stop:
"Stop smoking" (Quit).
"Stop to smoke" (Pause action to smoke).

explorer.hint: Like + -ing (also 'to swim', but -ing is common for hobby).

scholar.correctSentence: I don't mind waiting
She promised to help
We plan to visit Paris
He is good at drawing
Thank you for coming
It is important to study
Smoking is bad for you
She advised me to stay
I avoid eating sugar
I learned to drive

specialist.correctSentence: I used to like skiing
I look forward to seeing you
She manages to finish early
He suggests going by bus
It's easy to make mistakes
I'm interested in buying this
Don't forget to lock the door
I'll never forget meeting her
He quit smoking
She offered to pay

relative_clauses.title: Defining Relative Clauses
relative_clauses.subtitle: Who, Which, That - Identifying people or things.
relative_clauses.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Relative Clauses

1. Concept: Describing nouns using phrases.

  • Who: People ("The man who called").
  • Which/That: Things ("The car which I bought").
  • Where: Places ("The house where I live").
  • Whose: Possession ("The boy whose bike was stolen").

explorer.original: This is the man (who/which) helped me.
explorer.correctSentence: This is the man who helped me

explorer.original: I like the car (who/which) is red.
explorer.correctSentence: I like the car which is red
She is the girl who sings

explorer.original: That is the dog (who/which) bit me.
explorer.correctSentence: That is the dog which bit me

explorer.original: He is the teacher (who/which) teaches math.
explorer.correctSentence: He is the teacher who teaches math

explorer.original: Where is the book (who/which) I bought?
explorer.correctSentence: Where is the book which I bought

explorer.original: This is the house (who/which) Jack built.
explorer.correctSentence: This is the house which Jack built
I know someone who can help

scholar.correctSentence: That's the man that I saw
The phone that you broke
The place where we met
The time when we left

scholar.original: This is the person (whose) car was stolen.
scholar.correctSentence: This is the person whose car was stolen
The woman who lives next door

scholar.original: The keys (which) are on the table.
scholar.correctSentence: The keys which are on the table

scholar.original: A doctor is a person (who) helps sick people.
scholar.correctSentence: A doctor is a person who helps sick people

scholar.original: A pen is a thing (which) you write with.
scholar.correctSentence: A pen is a thing which you write with
The movie that we watched

specialist.original: The writer (whose) book won a prize.
specialist.correctSentence: The writer whose book won a prize
The city where I was born
The reason why he left
The man I spoke to
specialist.hint: Omitted relative pronoun (The man [who/that] I spoke to).

specialist.correctSentence: The book I am reading
That is what I mean

specialist.original: He is the only one (that) can do it.
specialist.correctSentence: He is the only one that can do it
All that glitters is not gold
The hotel we stayed at was nice
The person to whom I spoke

used_to.title: Used To
used_to.subtitle: Past habits that stopped.
used_to.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Used To

1. Concept: Past habits or states that are no longer true.

2. Structure: Used to + Base Verb.

3. Examples:
✅ "I used to play tennis." (I don't play now).
✅ "I didn't use to like olives." (Negative: Use 'use to').

explorer.correctSentence: You used to have a dog

scholar.correctSentence: I didn't use to like it
She didn't use to study
Did you use to play
Where did you use to live
He didn't use to eat meat
I used to have long hair
We never used to go there
scholar.hint: Never used to (British often 'used to' with never).

scholar.correctSentence: There used to be a park here
Did they use to fight
I used to drink milk

specialist.original: I (am used to) getting up early.
specialist.correctSentence: I am used to getting up early
specialist.hint: Be used to + -ing (Accustomed to) - Different meaning!

specialist.correctSentence: She is getting used to driving
I used to work hard
I am used to hard work
You will get used to it

specialist.original: Did you (use to) have a car?
specialist.correctSentence: Did you use to have a car

specialist.original: He (didn't use to) be so grumpy.
specialist.correctSentence: He didn't use to be so grumpy
We used to live in a flat

specialist.original: It takes time to (get used to) a new job.
specialist.correctSentence: It takes time to get used to a new job

specialist.original: I can't (get used to) the noise.
specialist.correctSentence: I can't get used to the noise

question_tags.title: Question Tags
question_tags.subtitle: Checking information, right?
question_tags.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Question Tags

1. Concept: Small questions at the end to confirm info.

2. Rule: Positive sentence -> Negative tag. Negative sentence -> Positive tag.

3. Examples:
✅ "You are happy, aren't you?"
✅ "She isn't here, is she?"
✅ "He likes pizza, doesn't he?" (Present Simple 's' -> Doesn't)

explorer.correctSentence: You don't like it do you
You have a car don't you
explorer.hint: Have (possession) uses do/don't in tags usually.

scholar.correctSentence: He likes pizza doesn't he
They play football don't they
You went to Paris didn't you
She didn't call did she
You have eaten haven't you
He will come won't he
We shouldn't go should we
You could help couldn't you
Let's go shall we
Don't do that will you

specialist.correctSentence: Nothing is wrong is it
Nobody called did they
Everyone is here aren't they
I am never late am I
You'd better go hadn't you
You'd like coffee wouldn't you
He hardly ever speaks does he
This is yours isn't it
Those are nice aren't they
Open the door will you

future_going_to_a2.title: Future: Going To
future_going_to_a2.subtitle: Plans and Predictions based on evidence.
future_going_to_a2.quickLesson:
⚡ Quick Lesson: Future (Going to)

1. Concept: Intentions and Evidence.

2. Examples:

  • Intention: "I'm going to study harder next year."
  • Evidence: "Look at the traffic. We are going to be late."

explorer.correctSentence: I am going to visit my grandma
She is going to buy a dress
They are going to play football
We are going to watch TV
He is going to cook dinner
You are going to clean the room
I am going to study English
We are going to eat pizza

scholar.correctSentence: I am not going to go out tonight
She is not going to buy it
Are you going to watch the game
What are you going to do tomorrow
Look The car is going to crash
Careful You are going to fall
We are going to have a baby
He is going to sell his house
When are they going to arrive
I am going to be sick

specialist.correctSentence: Why are you buying paint I am going to paint my room

specialist.original: I decided yesterday. I (quit) my job.
specialist.correctSentence: I am going to quit my job

specialist.original: Look at the time! We (miss) the train.
specialist.correctSentence: We are going to miss the train
She is going to faint
I am not going to tell him
You are not going to like it
Are you going to wear that dress

specialist.original: This traffic is terrible. We (be) late.
specialist.correctSentence: We are going to be late

specialist.original: I have saved money. I (travel) to Asia.
specialist.correctSentence: I am going to travel to Asia
Watch out The dog is going to bite you
